editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE TRIUMPHS OF JUSTICE OVER Vnju≈øt Iudges:

list.item: I. The Names and Crimes of Four and Forty Iudges Hang'd in one Year in England, as Murderers for their corrupt Judgments.
II. The Ca≈øe of the Lord Chief Justice Tre≈øilian, Hang'd at Tyburn, and all the re≈øt of the Judges of England (≈øave one) bani≈øht in K. Rich. the 2ds Time.
III. The Crimes of Emp≈øon and Dudley, Executed in K. Henry the 8th's Days.
IV. The Proceedings of the Ship-money-Judges in the Reign of K. Charles the Fir≈øt.
V. Diver≈øe other Pre≈øidents both Antient and Modern.
VI. The Judges OATH, and ≈øome Ob≈øervations thereupon.

div.p: Humbly Dedicated to the Lord Chief Iu≈øtice Scroggs.
div.q: Di≈øcite Justitiam moniti, & non temnere Leges.
div.p: LONDON, Printed for Benjamin Harris, at the Stationers Arms in the Piazza under the Royal Exchange. 1681.

div.head: TO Sir William Scroggs Kt. LORD CHIEF JUSTICE Of His Maje≈øties Court of KINGS-BENCH AT WESTMINTER.
div.p: I Know not to whom I could more properly Dedicate a Treati≈øe of this Nature, than to Your Lord≈øhip, who is at Pre≈øent Lord Chief Ju≈øtice of England, and have ≈øet ≈øuch remarkable Copies to inferior Magi≈øtrates. What is here offered, is neither Prophecy nor Plai≈øter, Lampoon, nor Romance; but a clear Mirrour retreiv'd out of the Clo≈øet of wi≈øe Antiquity, In which future Admini≈øtrators of publick Ju≈øtice would do well to Look; For you know, My Lord, Common-Law runs much upon Pre≈øidents; And if a Man happen to have none of the be≈øt Phy≈øiognomies, there is no rea≈øon why he ≈øhould ≈øtraight grow angry; and fling ≈øtones to break all the Looking-Gla≈ø≈øes he meets with, only becau≈øe they repre≈øent the true Figure of the Object.

'Tis a Priviledge we Scribblers that write for Bread, hold by Pre≈øcription, to put any great Bodies name in the front of our Book. Princes have not been able to exempt them≈øelves or their Favourites from the Per≈øecution of Dedications, nor
is there (I humbly conceive) any Rule made in Your Lord≈øhips Court to forbid them.

Suffer then, I be≈øeech Your Lord≈øhip this Addre≈øs to remain a Monument to Po≈øterity of the Sentiments this Age has of Your Lord≈øhips Conduct and Merits, and witne≈øs to all the world how much its Author, is

closer.signed: Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt humble Servant Philo-Dicaios.

div.head: THE TRIUMPHS OF JUSTICE OVER Vnju≈øt Iudges. &c.
div.p: UNdoubtedly there may be, becau≈øe there has been too often in the World; ≈øuch a thing, ≈øuch a ≈øin, ≈øuch a mi≈øchief, as Corruption of Iudges, that is, when by means of Pecuniary, or other Bribes, or (which is all out as bad) Threatnings, Promi≈øes of Reward, Malice, Revenge, hopes of greater, or fears of being turned out of pre≈øent Preferments, or any other ill motive; They that are appointed and Sworn to Admini≈øter equal and impartial Right and Ju≈øtice, are wrap'd a≈øide, or Bia≈ø'd to ≈øerve a Turn, or Wreck a private Grudge, or to free the Guilty, or condemn the Innocent; or to lean rather to the one ≈øide, than to the other; or wilfully to declare that to be Law, which they cannot but know is not ≈øo; or to adjudge puni≈øhments di≈øproportionate to the Crimes that appear before them, or any the like ba≈øe, illegal practi≈øes.

How odious this Vice is, to God and Man, as being equally de≈øtructive to Religion, and Humane Society; and how ≈øeverely it has been heretofore puni≈øhed, by both, may appear by The En≈øuing Examples.

1. As to God, who is Capitalis Ju≈øtitiarius Caeli & Terrae, the Grand never-erring Ju≈øtitiary of all the World. His Sacred Word prohibits nothing more po≈øitively, nor omplain of any thing lowder, or with more repeated importunities. Thou ≈øhalt not re≈øt the judgment of the poor in his cau≈øe; Thou ≈øhalt take no gift, for a gift blindeth the eye of the wi≈øe, and perverteth the words of the Righteous, Ex. 23.6 and 8 ver. Thou ≈øhalt not re≈øt juegment; thou ≈øhalt not re≈øpect per≈øons, neither take a gift, &c. Deut. 16.19. Woe unto them that ju≈øtifie the wicked for reward, and taketh away the righteou≈øne≈øs of the righteous from him, I≈øa. 5.23. A wicked man taketh a gift out of the bo≈øome ('tis done you ≈øee ≈ølyly, and in the dark) to pervert the ways of judgment, Prov. 17 23. Woe unto yee who turn judgment into wormwood, and leave off righteou≈øne≈øs in the earth, Amos 5.7. The good man is peri≈øhed out of the earth, and there is none upwright among≈øt men; They all lye in wait for bloud; they hunt every man his brother as with a net, that they may do evil with both hands earne≈øtly. The Prince asketh, and the Judg gapeth for a reward; and the great man uttereth his mi≈øchievous de≈øire, ≈øo they wrap
it up: the be≈øt of them is as a briar, the most upright is ≈øharper than a thorn-hedg, &c. Mic. 7.2, 3, & 4 ver. with many of the like Texts.

2, As corrupt Judges are thus obnoxious to the Cur≈øe of God, ≈øo hath his Divine Providence not ≈øeldome Executed it upon them even in this world by the hands of men. Nor indeed is there any thing that can render Kings (Gods Vicegerents) more Glorious, or better e≈øtabli≈øh any ≈øtate, than to keep the Current of Ju≈øtice clear and un≈øullied; and exemplarily to puni≈øh their Subordinate Mini≈øters, and e≈øpecially Judges that ≈øhall pre≈øume to impoi≈øon that Sacred Fountain.

Several Heathen Princes are Renowned for this whole≈øom ≈øeverity. 'Tis ≈øaid of Alexander Severus the Roman Emperour, that he had ≈øuch an aver≈øion and abhorrence of unju≈øt Judges, that at the very ≈øight of them he would vomit Choler, & was ready with his fingers to pluck out their eyes-Theatrum Hi≈øtoricum, f. 546.

The Mighty Monarch Camby≈øes, King of Per≈øia, finding that one Si≈øamnes his Chief Ju≈øtice (Proe≈øes our Author calls him in Latin) had receiv'd a Bribe, and for the ≈øame pronounced an unju≈øt Sentence, forthwith cau≈øed him to be Executed, and curiou≈øly flead, and with his skin cover'd the Common Seat of Ju≈øtice, and Con≈øtituted Otanes (the ≈øaid Si≈øamne≈ø's own Son) Judg in his Room; That ≈øo beholding daily tho≈øe Reliques of his ju≈øtly-puni≈øht Father; It might ≈øerve as a Memento to him to act more uprightly. Chronicon Carionis l. 2. p. 19.

But not to ≈øearch ≈øo far off, ‚Äî our own Nation affords us (perhaps) the mo≈øt notable and numerous Examples of Royal Ju≈øtice in this kind of any in the world. For we find it Recorded in that Antient Law-Book, Entituled The Mirrour of Ju≈øtices (mo≈øt of which is ≈øaid to be Compiled before the Conque≈øt, and Augmented by the Learned Andrew Horn in the Reign of K. Edw. the I≈øt. and which is often Cited by the Famous Lord Coke, and to this day continues in good Repute among≈øt Lawyers) That King Alfred, a Renowned Saxon-Prince, who Governed this Realm about the Year of our Lord 900. did in one years ≈øpace bring to Condign puni≈øhment, no fewer than four and forty of his Ju≈øtices, (≈øo the Law Terms tho≈øe we call Judges; and this was long before, either Ju≈øtices of the Peace E≈øtabli≈øht, or the Courts fixed at Westminster: But Ju≈øtice was in tho≈øe days Admini≈øtred in the Countrey, in Neighbouring Courts, which yet (as appears by the nature of the offences alledged again≈øt them) had jus vitae & necis, power of life and death, and ≈øo may properly be
called Judges) who≈øe Names and particular Crimes here follow in the words of that worthy Author, p. 296. of the French, and p. 239 of the Engli≈øh Edition.

It is an abu≈øe that Ju≈øtices and their Officers who kill People by fal≈øe judgment, be not de≈øtroyed, which King Alfred cau≈øed to be done, who cau≈øed Forty four Iu≈øtices in one year, to be hanged as Murderers fer their fal≈øe judgments.
1. He hanged Darling becau≈øe he judged Sidulf to death, for the retreat of Edulf his Son, who afterward; acquitted him of the Fact.
2. He hanged Segnar, who judged Ulf to death after ≈øufficient acquittal.

3. He hanged Cadwine, becau≈øe that he judged Hachwy to death without the Con≈øent of all the Jurors; for whereas he had put him≈øelf upon a jury of Twelve-men; & becau≈øe that three would have≈øaved him again≈øt the Nine: Cadwine removed the three and put others upon the jury, upon whom Hachwy put not him≈øelf.
4. He hanged Cole, becau≈øe he judged Ive to death when he was a Mad-man.
5. He hanged Malme, becau≈øe he Judged Prat to death upon a fal≈øe ≈øugge≈øtion that he committed the felony.
6. He hanged Athulf, becau≈øe he cau≈øed Copping to be hang'd before the Age of one and twenty years. [It was again≈øt Law then, but now nequitia ≈øupplet Aetatem.]
7. He hanged Markes, becau≈øe he judged During to death by twelve men that were not ≈øworn.
8. He hanged Ostline, becau≈øe he judged Seaman to death by a fal≈øe Warrant, grounded upon fal≈øe ≈øugge≈øtion, which ≈øuppo≈øed Seaman to be a Per≈øon in the warrant, which he was not.

9. He hanged Billing, becau≈øe he judged Leston to death by fraud: In this manner, he ≈øaid to the People, ≈øit all ye here but he who killed the man, and becau≈øe that Le≈øton did not ≈øit with the other, he commanded him to be hanged, and ≈øaid that he did a≈ø≈øi≈øt, where he knew he did not a≈ø≈øi≈øt to kill the Party.
10. He hanged Seafoul, becau≈øe he judged Ording to death, as not an≈øwering.
11. He hanged Thur≈øton, becau≈øe he judged Thurgner to death by a Verdict of Inque≈øt, taken ex officio, without I≈ø≈øue joyned.
12. He hanged Athel≈øton, becau≈øe he judged Herbert to death for an offence not mortal.
13. He hanged Rambold, becau≈øe he judged Le≈øchild in a Ca≈øe not notorious, without Appeal, and without Indictment.
14. He hanged Rolf, becau≈øe he judged Dun≈øton to dye for an e≈øcape out of pri≈øon.
15. He hanged Frebern, becau≈øe he judged Harpin to dye, whereas the July were in doubt of their verdict, for in doubtful ca≈øes one ough rather to ≈øave than condemn.
16. He hanged Seabright, who judged Athebrus to death, becau≈øe he had di≈øcharg'd one that had given a fal≈øe judgment in a Ca≈øe Capital.

17. He hanged Hale, becau≈øe he ≈øaved Tri≈øtrain the Sherif from death, who took to the Kings u≈øe from another goods again≈øt his will, for as much as any ≈øuch taking from another again≈øt his will, and Robbery hath no difference.

18. He hanged Arnold, becau≈øe he ≈øaved Bailifs, who robbed the people by colour of Di≈øtre≈ø≈øes; ≈øome by ≈øelling Di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, ≈øuch, and others by extortion of Fines; becau≈øe between ≈øuch tortious Acts and Robbery there was no difference.
19. He hanged Erkinwald, becau≈øe he hanged Frankling, for nought el≈øe, but becau≈øe he taught to him who vanqui≈øhed him by Battle-mortal to ≈øay the word Cravant.
20. He hanged Bermond, becau≈øe he cau≈øed Garbot to be beheaded by his judgment in England, for that, for which he was outlaw'd in Ireland.
21. He hanged Alkman, becau≈øe he ≈øaved Cateman by colour of Di≈ø≈øei≈øin, who was Attaited of Burglary.
22. He hanged Saxmond, becau≈øe he hanged Barold in England where the Kings Writ runneth for a fact which he did in the ≈øame Land, where the Kings Writ did not run.
23. He hanged Alflet, becau≈øe he judged a Clerk to death over whom he had no Cognizance.
24. He hanged Piron, becau≈øe he judged Huntiny to death; becau≈øe he gave judgment in Appeal before the forty days pendant; the Appeal by a Writ of fal≈øe judgment before the King.
25. He hanged Delani, becau≈øe he cau≈øed Eldons to be hanged, who kill'd a man by misfortune.
26. He hanged O≈øwin, becau≈øe he judged Fulcher to death out of Court.
27. He hanged Mucdin, becau≈øe he hanged Helgrave by warrant of Indictment not ≈øpecial.
He hanged Horn, becau≈øe he hanged Simin at days forbidden.
29. He hanged Wolmer, becau≈øe he judged Grant to death by colour of a Larceny, of a thing which he had received by Title of Bailment.

30. He hanged Therberne becau≈øe he Judged O≈øgot; to death for a Fact whereof he was Acquitted before again≈øt the ≈øame Plaintiffe; which Acquittance he tendred to averre by Oath, and becau≈øe he would not averre it by Record, Therbern would not allow of the Acquittal which he tendred him.

31. He hanged Wol≈øton becau≈øe he adjudged Howbert to death at the ≈øuit of the King, for a fact which Howbert confe≈øt, and of which the King gave him his Pardon, but he had no Charter thereof; neverthele≈øs he vouched the King to Warrant it, and further tendred to averre it by Enrollment of the Chancery.

32. He hanged Oskitell becau≈øe he Judged Cutlinge to death by the Record of the Coroner, where by Replication allowable, the Plea did not hold; And the Ca≈øe was ≈øuch, Cutling was taken and Tortured ≈øo much, as he confe≈ø≈øed he had Mortally offended, only to be quitted of the pain; and Oskitell adjudged him to death upon ≈øuch his Confe≈ø≈øion which he had made to the Coroner, without trial of the truth of the Torture or the Fact. And further the ≈øaid King cau≈øed the Coroners and Officers Acce≈ø≈øories to be apprehended who hanged the people, and all tho≈øe that might have hindred the fal≈øe Judgment, and did not hinder the ≈øame in all ca≈øes: For he hanged all the Judges who had fal≈øely ≈øaved any man guilty of Death; or hath fal≈øely hanged any man again≈øt Law, or any rea≈øonable Exception.

He hanged the Suitors of Calevot, becau≈øe they had adjudged a man to death in a ca≈øe not notorious, although he were guilty thereof; for no man can Judge within the Realm but the King, or his Commi≈ø≈øaries, except tho≈øe Lords in who≈øe Lord≈øhips the Kings Writ doth not run.
He hanged the Suitors of Dorce≈øter, becau≈øe they Judged a man to death by Jurors in their Liberty for a Felony done out of it, and whereof they had not the Conu≈øance by rea≈øon of forraignty.
He hanged the Suitors of Cirence≈øter, becau≈øe they kept a man ≈øo long in Pri≈øon, that he dyed in pri≈øon, who would have acquitted him≈øelf by Forraigners that he offended not Feloniou≈øly.
['Tis ≈øuppo≈øed the≈øe Suitors of each place were Four in Number, which compleats the number of 44. Hanged in all.]

In his time al≈øo the Suitors of Donca≈øter lo≈øt their Juri≈ødiction, be≈øides other Puni≈øhments, becau≈øe they held Pleas forbidden by the Cu≈øtoms of the Realm to Ordinary Judges and Suitors to hold.
In this time Colgrin lo≈øt his Franchi≈øe of Enfangthief, becau≈øe he would not ≈øend a Thief to the common Gaole of the County, who was taken within his Liberty, and not Bailable.

In this time Buttolph lo≈øt his view of Frank-pledges becau≈øe he charged the Jurours with other Articles than tho≈øe which belonged to the View, and Amerced people in per≈øonal Actions where one was not to be amerced by a pecuniary Puni≈øhment: And accordingly he cau≈øed puni≈øhments of Death to Criminal Judges for wrongful mortal Judgements, and ≈øo he did proportionably for wrongful Judgements of a le≈ø≈øer nature: As Impri≈øonment for wrongful Impri≈øonments, and and like for like with the other Puni≈øhments; for he delivered Thelweld to Pri≈øon, becau≈øe he Judged men to Pri≈øon for Offences where they ought not to be Impri≈øoned.
He Judged Lithing to Pri≈øon becau≈øe he impri≈øoned Herbote for the Offence of his Wife.
He Judged Rutwood to Pri≈øon becau≈øe he Impri≈øoned Old for the Kings Debt.
[Note, In tho≈øe days people were not to be Impri≈øoned for Debt, but only their Goods di≈øtrain'd.]
On the other ≈øide, he Cut off the Hand of Haulf, becau≈øe he ≈øaved Armorks Hand, who was Attainted before him, that he had Feloniou≈øly wounded Richbold.
He Judged Edulfe to be wounded, becau≈øe he Judged not Arnold to be wounded, who had Feloniou≈øly wounded Aldens.

In le≈ø≈øer Judgments he did not meddle with the Judgments; but Di≈øinherited the Ju≈øtices, and Removed them according to the Points of tho≈øe Statutes, where he could under≈øtand that they had Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed their Juri≈ødiction, or the Bounds of their Delegacy or Commi≈ø≈øion; or had concealed Fines or Amerciaments or ought that belonged to the King, or had Relea≈øed or Increa≈øed any Puni≈øhment contrary to Law, or procured Pleadings without Warrant, &c.
Thus far Horns Mirrour.

Now that this Alfred was one of the Wi≈øe≈øt and mo≈øt Renowned Kings that ever this Land was happily Governed by, appears, as well by the Eulogies given him by the Ancients, as tho≈øe Encomia≈øtick Ver≈øes Dedicated to his Memory, by a pre≈øent Ingenious Courtier, Sir Win≈øton Churchill, Kt. in his Diri Britannici, Fol. 140.

q.l: Who would not follow him into the Field,
Who cannot choo≈øe but Conquer tho' he yield?
Who≈øe Sword cut deep, yet was his Wit more keen,
Some Fence 'gain≈øt that; But this did wound un≈øeen.
To thee is due (Great Elfrid!) double prai≈øe;
To thee we bring the Laurel and the Bayes.
Ma≈øter of Arts and Arms, Apollo ≈øo
Sometimes did u≈øe his Harp, ≈øometimes his Bow,
And from the other Gods got this Renown
To Reconcile the Gauntlet to the Gown.
But who did e're with the ≈øame Sword like Thee,
Keep up at once the Law of Arms and Peace,
And from the Camp I≈ø≈øue out Writs of Ea≈øe.

div.p: The next Engli≈øh Prince of Renown before the Norman Conque≈øt, was King Edgar, about the year 960. Among≈øt who≈øe Noble Acts 'tis recorded as none of the lea≈øt memorable, that in his Circuits and Progre≈ø≈øes through the Countrey, he would take Account of the Demeanour of his Lords, and e≈øpecially of his Judges, whom he ≈øeverely Puni≈øhed, if he found them Delinquents: Bakers Chron. Fol. 11.
Nor have the be≈øt and wi≈øe≈øt of our Princes ≈øince the Conque≈øt, been le≈øs ready to give up Ill Judges to ju≈øt Puni≈øhment, nor our Engli≈øh Parliaments wanting to bring them to it.

In the pear 1290. being (≈øaith Wal≈øingham, p. 54.) the 17th year of Edw. 1. Ju≈øtitiarios fer√® omnes de fal≈øitate deprehen≈øos a ≈øuo Officio depo≈øuit ip≈øos juxta merita puniens gravi Mulct√¢. He finding almo≈øt all his Judges guilty of Corruption, put them out of their places, and Puni≈øht them according to their Demerits with heavy Fines. Which the Lord Cook in the Second part of his In≈øtitutes, Fol. 508. likewi≈øe takes notice of, and tells us, That this was done by a Parliament held after the Fea≈øt of
St. Hillary, and only two Judges ≈øcap'd ≈øcot-free. But how ≈øevere the Fines of the other Delinquents were, appears in Bakers Chronicle, fol. 100. Sir Ralph de Hengham (≈øays he) Chief Ju≈øtice of the Kings-Bench, for Corruption was Fined 7000 Marks; Sir John Lovetot one of the Ju≈øtices of the Common Pleas 3000 Marks; Sir William Brompton 6000 Marks; Sir Solomon Roche≈øter 4000 Marks; Sir Richard Boyland 4000 Marks; Sir Walter Hopton 2000 Marks; Sir William Saham in 3000 Marks; Robert Lithbury Ma≈øter of the Rolls in 1000 Marks; Roger Leice≈øter in 1000 Marks; Hugh Bray E≈øcheator and Judge for the Jews, 1000 Marks; But Sir Adam Stratton Chief Baron of the Exchequer (who it ≈øeems had been a notable Bribe-fingerer) four and thirty Thou≈øand Marks, [A prodigious Summe allmo≈øt 400 years ago!] And Sir Thomas Wayland Chiefe Ju≈øtice of the Common-Pleas being found the greate≈øt Offender of all, was Attainted of Felony for taking of Bribes, and his Lands and Goods Forfeited: as appears in the Pleas of Parliament, 18 Edw. 1. And he was al≈øo Bani≈øht the Kingdom, as unworthy to live in that State again≈øt which he had ≈øo much Offended.

Sir William Thorp Chief Ju≈øtice of the Kings-Bench in K. Edw. the Thirds time, having of five ≈øeveral per≈øons received five ≈øeveral Bribes, which in all amounted to 100 l. was for this alone adjudged to be Hang'd, and all his Goods and Lands Forfeited.

The rea≈øon of the Judgment is entred in the Roll in the≈øe words ‚Äî Quia praedictus Willielmus Thorpe qui Sacramentum Domini Regis erga populum ≈øuum habuit ad Cu≈øtodiendum, fregit malitio≈ø√®, fal≈ø√® & Rebelliter quantum in ip≈øo fuit. Becau≈øe that as much as in him lay, he had broken the Kings Oath made to the People, which the King had Intru≈øted him withall.

And ≈øo much did the then Collective Wi≈ødom of the Nation re≈øpect Judges herein, that 'tis expre≈øly entred, that this Judgment ≈øhould not be drawn into example again≈øt any other Officers who ≈øhould break their Oaths, but only again≈øt tho≈øe, Qui predictum Sacramentum fecerunt et fregerunt, et habent Leges Angliae ad Cu≈øtodiendum. That is, only to the Judges that violate their Oaths, having the Laws of England Entru≈øted unto them.

This Iudgment was given 24 Edw. 3 d. The next year in the Parliament 25 Edw. 3. Numero 10. it was debated in Parliament, Whether this Iudgment was Legal, and Nullo Contradicente, unanimou≈øly it was declared to be ju≈øt and according to the Law, and that the ≈øame Iudgment may be given in time to come upon the like occa≈øion. Which Ca≈øe, I humbly conceive, re≈øolves the Ca≈øe in Law Point Blank thus: That it is death for any Judge wittingly to break his Oath in any part of it. This Oath of Thorp is entred in the Roll, and is the ≈øame verbatim, with the Iudges Oath in 18 Edw. 3: The ≈øame too (as I humbly conceive) which our Iudges now a days take, and is herein afterwards punctually recited.

The Oaths of our Iudges of England, as they bind them to the due Admini≈øtration of Iu≈øtice to the Subject, according to the Laws, (which are every Free-mans Birth-Right) ≈øo al≈øo, as they be of the Kings Council, they are by ≈øuch their Oaths oblig'd, lawfully to coun≈øel him, that is, whenever their opinions are demanded, they are ≈øworn and bound to deliver them according to the Law.‚ÄîLet us ≈øee how our Ance≈øtors re≈øented the≈øe matters.

In a Parliament held in the 11th year of Richard the 2. there was Iudgment of High-Trea≈øon given again≈øt 18 ≈øeveral Per≈øons, and all, ≈øave one of them, of Eminent Rank; Three Privy Coun≈øelors, viz. The Archbi≈øhop of York, The Duke of Ireland, and Earl of Suffolk, the Bi≈øhop of Exeter, the Kings Confe≈ø≈øour, Five Knights, of whom ≈øome had been Servants to Edw. the 3. and all, but one, Servants to the then King, and ≈øome of them of Noble De≈øcent; but that which I more particularly ob≈øerve, there were among≈øt them Six Judges, and Locton the Kings Serjeant at Law; Blake of the Kings Council at Law, and Usk the under-Sheriff of Middle≈øex.

Of the≈øe 18, 8 were Executed, that is, Sir Robert Tre≈øilian, the Lord Chief Iu≈øtice was drawn from the Tower, through the mid≈øt of London, to Tyburn, and there Hanged; ≈øo likewi≈øe were Usk and Blake, and Sir Iohn Salisbury; but the other 4 Knights had the Favour to be Beheaded.
Three, that is, the Archbi≈øhop of York, the Duke of Ireland, and the Earl of Suffolk, died mi≈øerable Fugitives in forreign Parts.

The other ≈øeven (whereof five were Judges) with much ado got a Pardon as to Life, but were bani≈øhed, and their Lands and
Goods all forfeited; and it was made Felony for any to procure their Recalling home, and them≈øelves forthwith to be executed as Traytors, if at any time they ≈øhould pre≈øume to return.
And of the≈øe eighteen Per≈øons, all ≈øave three were impeached by the Commons.
The Offences which procured the≈øe Exemplary Puni≈øhments, were briefly the≈øe:

King Richard the II. being an unthinking di≈ø≈øolute Prince, by the ill coun≈øel of ≈øome near his Per≈øon, there had during his minority happened divers mi≈øcarriages in the Government: To redre≈øs which, in a Parliament holden in the tenth year of his Reign, and the twentieth of his Age, a Commi≈ø≈øion was awarded to Twelve Peers, and others of greate≈øt Wi≈ødom and Ability, impowering them to in≈øpect the pa≈øt management of the Hou≈øhold, the Revenue, the Courts of Ju≈øtice, and in a word, all things that did concern the Good of the Realm; with full power finally to determine, and put all things in excution, ≈øo as might mo≈øt tend to the Honour of the King, Relief of the People, and Safety of the Land; which Commi≈øsion was to endure onely one year.

Now come five of the Per≈øons above-named, viz. the Archbi≈øhop, the Duke, the Earl of Suffolk, the Chief Ju≈øtice, and Brembre, who ≈øeeing them≈øelves like to be called to Account for their pernitious Coun≈øels and Irregularities, and to be brought to de≈øerved ≈øhame and puni≈øhment; to avoid the ≈øame, and continue their Villanies for the future, they in≈øinuated to the King, That this Commi≈øsion intrenched upon the Royal Power, and was derogatory to the Crown, that the procurers thereof had extorted His Royal A≈ø≈øent thereunto in Parliament; and that this was Trea≈øon: for ≈øo the Chief Ju≈øtice and Blake the Kings Council, who was advi≈øed withal in the Writ, declared it to be; whereupon Blake was commanded to prepare an Indictment of Trea≈øon again≈øt all the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners, and again≈øt ≈øuch others as had been mo≈øt active in procuring that Authority: Accordingly he draws the Indictment which ≈øtands entred in the Roll, and is to this effect, That they the ≈øaid Commis≈øioners, &c. had Traiterou≈øly con≈øpired among them≈øelves to make this Commis≈øion by Authority of Parliament again≈øt the Royalty of the King, to his di≈øheri≈øon, and in derogation of the Crown, and that they forced the Kings Con≈øent, and confederated them≈øelves to maintain one another in ≈øo doing.

It was de≈øigned that they ≈øhould be tryed upon this Indictment in Middle≈øex or London, and therefore (≈øome of the parties to be pro≈øecuted not being Peers) Usk the Under-Sheriff of Middle≈øex was acquainted with the bu≈øine≈øs, (who was to return a Pack'd-Iury (you ≈øee that's a very old Game) that might be ≈øure to do the bu≈øine≈øs, which he performing accordingly, was therefore hang'd.

But further, the five grand Favourites, that the King might the more confide in their Coun≈øels, (for ≈øo are the words of the Record) and that under colour of Law, they might cover their malice from the King and the Kingdom, before the Trials were to be brought on, advi≈øe the King to demand the Opinion of ≈øome of the Judges, that is, of the two Chief Ju≈øtices and Chief Baron, and the Judges of the Common-Pleas, ≈øix in all in number, and of Locton the Kings Serjeant; Blake, of the Kings Council at Law, was commanded to draw up tho≈øe Que≈øtions, who did it accordingly, and for drawing the ≈øame, and the before-mentioned Indictment, he was him≈øelf Drawn and Hanged.
The Que≈øtions being prepared in Writing; the Iudges were ≈øent for to Nottingham Ca≈øtle, where in the Kings own Pre≈øence, they were commanded upon their Allegiance to deliver their Opinions,

list.item: 1. Whether the Commis≈øion was derogatory to the Rights of the Crown? They an≈øwered, It was.
2. Whether the per≈øuading and urging the King to con≈øent thereunto in Parliament, was Trea≈øon? They an≈øwered, That it was.

div.p:
Here were other Que≈øtions ask'd, but the≈øe were the Main, and tho≈øe for which they were condemned, as appears by the Replication of the Commons to the Iudges An≈øwer, and by the Words of the Iudgment ‚Äî That they the ≈øaid Iudges knew that this Commis≈øion was awarded in Parliament, &c. that it was for the Publick Good; That they knew of the Traiterous Intent to de≈øtroy the Procurers of this Commis≈øion; That they knew the Law, and that it was not Trea≈øon, and had delivered ≈øuch Opinions thereby, under colour of Law, to cover their Trea≈øonable Intent, and therefore Iudgment of High-Trea≈øon was given again≈øt them, and again≈øt Locton the Kings Serjeant, who had Sub≈øcribed the≈øe Fal≈øe Opinions with the Iudges. And though there be other Articles again≈øt the Re≈øt, yet this alone is adjudged Trea≈øon, in the ≈øeveral Iudgments again≈øt every one of the Eighteen: And 'tis ob≈øervable, That in all the≈øe Iudgments, they are adjudged
Traitors as well again≈øt the Per≈øon of the King, as again≈øt the Common-wealth.

And it is there declared upon great Advice taken, That in Trea≈øons which concern the King and Kingdom, they are not bound to proceed according to the Rules of the Common-Law, but according to the Cour≈øe of Parliaments, ≈øo as may be for the Common-Good. Nor were the≈øe Iudgments huddled up in ha≈øte, but given upon long and mature Deliberation, the Work of a Whole Parliament. And it is declared in the Roll, That they ≈øpent long time, and took great pains in examining the Evidence, the better thereby to ≈øatisfie their own Con≈øciences and the World. Their Proceedings again≈øt the five Plotters were begun the 14 of Novemb. and the Iudgments were not given till the 15 of Feb. following, which is a Quarter of a Year.

'Tis al≈øo to be ob≈øerved, That ≈øeveral of the≈øe Iudges were very unwilling to give their Corrupt Opinions, but were menaced and violently drawn thereunto by the Duke of Ireland and others. And at their Trials, they ≈øeverally Alledged, That in part Violence had been offered to their Per≈øons, becau≈øe they had deferred the delivery of their Opinions. But as Fear or Cowardice is no Plea for delivering up of the Forts or Bulwarks of the Kingdom, ≈øo neither is it for ba≈øely betraying our Rights and Liberties. The≈øe Allegations of being threatned from their Duty, could not excu≈øe them from the Rope: but how much more then do they de≈øerve it who ≈øhall pre≈øume to do as bad things or wor≈øe, without any Menaces at all, but wilfully and pre≈øumptuou≈øly, purely out of their own ba≈øe inclinations?

But Tre≈øilian was not the onely Iudge which our Engli≈øh Hi≈øtory, even ≈øince the Conque≈øt, mentions to have been executed for irregular Practices: For in the Reign of King Henry the Seventh, a Wi≈øe but Avaritious Prince, there were two Gentlemen of the Long Robe, that for private Intere≈øt, and to ≈øerve the Kings pre≈øent Turn, were ready to di≈øpence with their Oaths, and the known Fundamental Laws. But as they liv'd hated during his time, ≈øo they died unlamented under his Succe≈ø≈øor, being given up a nece≈ø≈øary Sacrifice to Publick Iustice.
There is no Per≈øon in the World more Haughty, or an Apter Tool for Oppre≈ø≈øion, than a Beggars Bratt, or ≈øome ba≈øe Mechanick, Butcherly Off-≈øpring, when unde≈øervedly flu≈øh't with Preferment.

The King made odd U≈øe of the≈øe Two In≈øtruments. They turn'd (≈øayes Baker) Law into Rapine. And mo≈øt certain it is, that many ill Things they did: But the better to colour their vile Practi≈øes, a Statute was Provided, to Ju≈øtify their Inva≈øions on the Liberties and Properties of their Fellow-Subjects.
We will give you an Account of this Matter, in the very Words of that Great Oracle of our Law, Sir Edward Cook. But fir≈øt, hear how Sir Richard Baker, in his Chronicle, fol. 247. repre≈øents them:

p.q:
Their Manner was (≈øaith he) to cau≈øe divers Subjects to be Indicted of Crimes, and then pre≈øently to Commit them, and not Produce them to their An≈øwer, but ≈øuffer them to Langui≈øh long in Pri≈øon; and by ≈øundry Artificial Devices and Terror, extort from them great Fines, which they termed Compo≈øitions and Mitigations. Neither did they (towards the End) ob≈øerve ≈øo much as the Half-Face of Ju≈øtice, in Proceeding by Indictment; but ≈øent forth their Precepts to Attach Men, and Convent them before Them≈øelves, and ≈øome Others, at their private Hou≈øes; and there ≈øhuffle up a Summary Proceeding by Examination, Without Tryal by Iury; a≈ø≈øuming to them≈øelves to deal both in Pleas of the Crown, and Controver≈øies Civil. Then did they al≈øo u≈øe to Enthral, and Charge the Subjects Land with Tenures in Capite, by finding Fal≈øe Offices, refu≈øing upon divers Pretexts and Delayes, to admit Men to Traver≈øe tho≈øe Fal≈øe Offices. Nay, contrary to all Law and Colour, they maintain'd, That the King ought to have the Half of Mens Lands and Rents, during the Space of full Two Years, for a Pain, in ca≈øe of Outlawry. They would likewi≈øe Ruffle with Jurors, and enforce them to Find, as they would Direct: And if they did not, then Convent, Impri≈øon, and Fine them. The≈øe, and many other Cour≈øes they had, of Preying upon the People, and had ever a Rabble of Promoters, and Leading Jurors at their Command, ≈øo
as they could have any Thing found, either for Fact, or Valuation.

div.p: Thus far the Hi≈øtorian. Now, take the Relation of the Reverend Judge Cook, in his ever-valuable Works, Commenting in the Second Part of his In≈øtitutes on that GOLDEN Nine and Twentyeth Chapter of Magna Charta; which being of Ine≈øtimable Value, I take it for granted, no True Engli≈øh Man will any more grudge the Reading, than I do the Recital of it; and I wi≈øh it might every Market-Day, be repeated with a Speaking-Trumpet, in every Town and Corporation of this Kingdom. The Words run thus: Nullus Liber Homo, &c.

p.q: No Free-Man ≈øhall be Taken, or Impri≈øoned, or Di≈ø≈øei≈øed of his Free-Tenement or Liberties, or Free-Cu≈øtoms; or be Out-law'd, or Exil'd, or in any manner De≈øtroy'd: Nor will we pa≈øs upon him, nor ≈øend any (to pa≈øs) upon him: But by the Lawful Judgment of his Peers, or by the Law of the Land. We will Sell to none, we will Deny to none, nor to any delay Ju≈øtice or Right.

div.p: Di≈øcour≈øing, I ≈øay, upon this mo≈øt Comprehen≈øive Text, the Corner-Stone of all our Engli≈øh Freedoms, my Lord Cook, 2 In≈øtit. fol. 51. thus expre≈ø≈øes him≈øelf:

Again≈øt this Antient and Fundamental Law, and in the Face thereof, I find an Act of Parliament made 11 H. 7. Cap. 3. That as well Ju≈øtices of A≈ø≈øize, as Ju≈øtices of the Peace, (without any Finding, or Pre≈øentment by the Verdict of Twelve Men) upon a bare Information for the King, before them made, ≈øhould have full Power and Authority, by their Di≈øcretions, to Hear and Determine all Offences, &c.
And Fourth Part, In≈øtit. fol. 39. he gives a further Account of, and Recites this Act thus:

q.p:
There was an Act of Parliament made in the 11 H. 7. which had a Fair, Flattering Preamble, pretending to avoid divers Mi≈øchiefs, which were, 1. The High Di≈øplea≈øure of Almighty God. 2. The great Let of the Common-Law. And, 3. The great Let of the Wealth of this Land. And the Purview of that Act tended in the Execution contrary, Ex Diametro, viz. To the Di≈øplea≈øure of Almighty God, The
great Let, nay, the utter Subver≈øion of the Common-Law, and, The great Let of the Wealth of this Land; Which Act followeth in the≈øe Words:

p.q:
THe King our Soveraign Lord, calling to his Remembrance, That many good Statutes, and Ordinances be made for the Puni≈øhment of Riots, and unlawful A≈ø≈øemblies, Reteinders in giving, and receiving of Liveries, Signs, and Tokens unlawfully, Extortions, Maintenances, Imbracery, Exce≈ø≈øive taking of Wages, contrary to the Statute of Labourers and Artificers, the V≈øe of unlawful Games, Inordinate Apparel, &c. to the di≈øplea≈øure of Almighty God, &c. notwith≈øtanding that generally, by the Iu≈øtices of the Peace, in every Shire within this Realm, in the open Se≈ø≈øions, it is given in Charge to inquire of many Offences committed, &c. and divers Inque≈øts thereupon ≈øtraightly Sworn, and Charged before the ≈øaid Iu≈øtices to inquire of the Premi≈ø≈øes, and therein to pre≈øent the Troth, which they letted to be ≈øound by Imbracery, Maintenance, Corruption, and Favour; by occa≈øion whereof, the ≈øaid Statutes be not nor cannot be put in due Execution: For Reformation whereof, for≈øomuch that before this time the ≈øaid Offences, Extortions, Contempts, &c. might not, nor as yet may be conveniently Puni≈øhed by the due Order of Law, except it were fir≈øt found, and pre≈øented by the Verdict of Twelve
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ en thereto duely Sworn, who for the Cau≈øes before Recited will not find, nor pre≈øent the Truth; wherefore be it by the Advice, and A≈ø≈øent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and the Commons in this pre≈øent Parliament A≈ø≈øembled, and by Authority of the ≈øame Enacted, Ordained, and E≈øtabli≈øhed; That from henceforth, as well the Iu≈øtices of A≈ø≈øize as the Iu≈øtices of the Peace, in every County of the ≈øaid Realm upon Information [Note, it was to be without any Pre≈øentment, or Indictment found by any Grand or Petty Jury] for the King, &c. ≈øhall have full Power, & Authority by their Di≈øcretion to hear, & determine all Offences, &c.

div.p: Here you ≈øee Matters were left to be determined by Judges, and Ju≈øtices Without Iuries, in a Summary, Chancery-Method, only according for≈øooth! to their Di≈øcretion: Yet ≈øtill there was a Provi≈øo,

p.hi: THat no ≈øuch Information ≈øhould extend to Trea≈øon, Murder, or Felony; nor to any other Offence, for which any Per≈øon ≈øhould lo≈øe Life or Member: Nor to lo≈øe by, or upon the ≈øame Information, any Lands, Tenements, Goods, or Chatteis, to the Party making the ≈øame Information.

div.p: [Which de≈øerves Particular Notice:] Yet ob≈øerve, how the ≈øame Reverend Lord Coolt, in the Place before-cited, de≈øcants on this Act.

By Pretext (≈øaith he) of this Law, Emp≈øon and Dudley did commit upon the Subject un≈øufferable Pre≈ø≈øures and Oppre≈ø≈øions; and therefore, this Statute was Justly, ≈øoon after the Decea≈øe of Henry the Seventh, Repeal'd by an Act of Parliament, 1 H. 8. Cap. 8. A good Caveat to Parliaments, to leave all Cau≈øes to be mea≈øured by that Golden, and Strait-Mete-Wand of the Law, and not to the incertain and crooked Cord of Di≈øcretion.

It is not almo≈øt Credible, (continues the ≈øame Judicious Author) to fore-≈øee, when any Maxim, or Fundamental-Law of this Realm [He means, as to this particular Ca≈øe, Tryals per Pais, that is, by Juries] is Altered, what dangerous Inconveniences do follow. Which mo≈øt expre≈øly appears by this Mo≈øt Vnju≈øt & Strange Act: For hereby, not only Emp≈øon and Dudley them≈øelves; but ≈øuch Ju≈øtices of Peace, Corrupt Men as they cau≈øed to be Authorized, Committed mo≈øt grievous and heavy Oppre≈ø≈øions and Exactions, Grinding of the Faces of poor Subjects by Penal Laws, be they never ≈øo Ob≈øolete, or unfit for the Time, [Suppo≈øe, for a Parallel in our Times, putting the Statutes again≈øt Popi≈øh Recu≈øants, in Execution again≈øt Prote≈øtant Di≈ø≈øenters, at a Juncture when Popery was ju≈øt ready to over-run us all] by Information only, without any Pre≈øentment or Tryal by Jury, being The Antient Birth-Right of the Subject: But to Hear and Determine the ≈øame, by their Di≈øcretion. The≈øe, and other like Oppre≈ø≈øions and Exactions by, or by Means of Emp≈øon and Dudley, and their In≈øtruments, brought Infinite Trea≈øures to the King's Coffers; whereof the King, in the End, with great Grief and Compunction, Repented.

This Statute of 11 H. 7 We have Recited, and ≈øhewed the Inconveniencies thereof; to the end, that the like ≈øhould never hereafter be attempted in any Court of Parliament: And that others might avoid the Fearful End of the≈øe Two Time-Servers, Emp≈øon and Dudley.
Thus far that Oracle of our Engli≈øh Laws. Wherein be plea≈øed to ob≈øerve:

First, That he ≈øticks not to call even an Act of Parliament, mo≈øt Vnju≈øt and Strange: And in the Second Part of his In≈øtitutes, fol. 51. Vnju≈øt and Injurious; becau≈øe it Altered a Fundamental-Law of the Realm, viz. Denyed Tryal by Juries, a mo≈øt E≈ø≈øential Part of Engli≈øh Freedom, and never to be parted with.

Secondly, Ob≈øerve what became of the≈øe Two Wicked Men, though they had ≈øuch a Colour of Law to bear them out: They were, in the Beginning of the Reign of King Henry the Eighth, (fir≈øt) Indicted for other ba≈øe Practi≈øes, in Finding of Fal≈øe Offices for the King, to the Dammage and Di≈øheri≈øon of His Subjects: Which Indictment ran as follows (≈øee Cook's In≈øtit. Part the Fourth, fol. 198.)

body.head: Juratores prae≈øentant quod Richardus Emp≈øon nuper de London Miles, &c. In Engli≈øh thus:
body.p:
THe Jurors pre≈øent, That Richard Emp≈øon, late of London, Knight, late Coun≈øellor of the mo≈øt Excellent Prince, Henry the Seventh, late King of England, on the Tenth Day of May, in the Twentyeth Year of the ≈øaid late King, and divers Times before and after, at London, &c. Not having God before his Eyes; but as the Son of the Devil, imagining the Honour, Dignity, and Pro≈øperity of the ≈øaid late King; and the Pro≈øperity of His Kingdom of England, not at all to Value or Regard: But to the end, that he might obtain to be a more Singular Favourite of the ≈øaid late King, whereby he Him≈øelf might be made a Noble or Great Man, and Govern the whole Kingdom of England at his Plea≈øure; Fal≈øly, Deceitfully, and Trea≈øonably Subverting the La ‚Ä¢ y of England, did (among≈øt other Things) the Day and Year afore-≈øaid, at London, in the Pari≈øh and Ward afore-≈øaid, procure, and cau≈øe to be found divers fal≈øe Inqui≈øitions, and Offices of Intru≈øions, and Alienations of
divers Leige-Subject's Mannors, Lands, and Tenements; that they held the Mannors, Lands, and Tenements in tho≈øe Inqui≈øitions ≈øpecified of our Lord the King, in Capite, or otherwi≈øe; when in Truth it was not ≈øo. And afterwards, when the ≈øaid Leige-Subjects of our Lord, the late King, would have tendered and alledged Traver≈øes to the ≈øaid Inqui≈øitions, in the Court of Him, the ≈øaid late King, according to the Law of England; they could not be admitted to tho≈øe Traver≈øes: But he, the ≈øaid Richard Emp≈øon, debar'd and delay'd them from the ≈øame, 'till they had agreed with him, to pay divers Great and In≈øupportable Fines and Redemptions; as well for the Profit of the ≈øaid late King, as for the proper, private Advantages of him, the ≈øaid Richard; to the great Impoveri≈øhment of the ≈øaid Subjects. And that the ≈øaid Richard, the Day and Year afore-≈øaid, in the Pari≈øh and Ward afore-≈øaid, and ≈øeveral Times before and after, divers Leige-Subjects of the ≈øaid late King, holding of out ≈øaid Lord the King, divers Mannors, Lands, and Tenements, by Knight's-Service, and them≈øelves being (by the Death of their Ance≈øtors) under Age, and ≈øo in the Ward≈øhip of the King, by Rea≈øon of their Tenure, when they came to lawful Age, and ought to have had due Livery of their Mannors, Lands, and Tenements, according to the Cu≈øtom and Law of England, and would have Pro≈øecuted the ≈øame according to the Cour≈øe of Chancery; did refu≈øe them ≈øo to do, and totally deny and erclude; until they had made with him, the ≈øaid Richard, divers great Fines and Redemptions, more than they could bear; as well for the Gain of the ≈øaid late King, as for the private Benefit of him, the ≈øaid Richard: Whereby many of the ≈øaid late King's People were by ≈øuch Grievances, and Vnju≈øt Extortions many wayes vered: In≈øomuch, that the Subjects of the ≈øaid late King, did manifoldly murmur, and bear ill Will again≈øt the ≈øaid late King; to the great Peril of Him, the ≈øaid late King, His Kingdom of England, and the Subver≈øion of the Laws and Cu≈øtoms of this Realm.

div.p: 'Tis true, (≈øaith my Lord Cook, Fourth Part of his In≈øtitutes, fol. 41.) in this Indictment [Which, Mutatis mutandis, we are to ≈øuppo≈øe, was alike again≈øt Dudley] the Word Proditorie, [That is to ≈øay, Trea≈øonably] was u≈øed but for Aggravation, and as a Preparative (for a Pro≈øecution) to Greater Offences. For they were not to e≈øcape with a Charge of Mi≈ødemeanor only: But in the ≈øame Year, they were both Indicted of High-Trea≈øon, both by the Common-Law, and Act of Parliament. And in the Second Year of King Henry the Eighth, they both Lo≈øt their Heads.

Thus, that Profound Judge ≈øpeaks of them, who 4. In≈øtit. fol. 41. concludes the Story of the≈øe Time-≈øerving, Self-de≈øigning Judges, with this mo≈øt remarkable Epiphonema: Qui eorum ve≈øtigiis in≈øi≈øtunt, eorum Exitus prehorre≈øcant; Tho≈øe that ≈øhall dare tread their Steps, let them dread (or expect) the like di≈ømal Ends.

Sir Richard Baker, the Be≈øt perhaps (for want of a better) of our Modern Engli≈øh Hi≈øtorians, gives ≈øomewhat a more particular Account of the Fate of the≈øe Two Corrupt Huck≈øters of Law and Ju≈øtice: Which be pleas'd to Peru≈øe in his own Words, fol. 254.
Speaking of King Henry the Eighth's general Pardon, at his fir≈øt coming to the Crown, and how he Ordered Re≈øtitution to be made, of all Goods unju≈øtly taken from any. He Adds:

q.p: And becau≈øe the In≈øtruments of ≈øuch Inju≈øtice are Always mo≈øt Odious; and nothing gives the People ≈øo much Contentment, as to ≈øee their Per≈øecutors Puni≈øhed. He therefore cau≈øed Emp≈øon and Dudley, the Two Chief Actors of the late unju≈øt Proceedings, to be Committed to the Tower, and divers of their Inferior Agents, called Promoters [The Raskally Informers, Pen≈øionary Affidavit-Men, or (if you plea≈øe) Robin Hogg's of that Age] As Camby, Page, Derby, Wight, Simp≈øon, and Storckton, to be ≈øet on the Pillory in Cornhil, with Papers on their Heads, and then to Ride through the City with their Faces to the Hor≈øe-Tails, with the ≈øhame whereof, in Seven Days after they all Dyed in Newgate.

Shortly after a Parliament was called; whereof Sir Thomas Ingleby was cho≈øen Speaker: And therein Emp≈øon, and Dudley were Accu≈øed of High-Trea≈øon, and after Arraigned; Edmund Dudley, in Guild-Hall, on the Seventeenth of July; and Sir Richard Emp≈øon at Northampton, in October following. And on the Seventeenth of Augu≈øt, the Year following, [Which was Anno Domini, 1510.] they were both of them Beheaded on the Tower-Hill; and their Bodies and Heads Buryed, the one at White-Fryars, the other at the Black.

div.p: And al≈øo, by an Act of 1 H. 8th. Cap. 6. the before-recited Injurious Statute of 11 H. 7. was made void, and repeal'd; and the Rea≈øon thereof is yielded, for that by Force of the ≈øaid Act it was manife≈øtly known, that many Sini≈øter and Crafty, Feigned, and Forged Informations, had been pur≈øued again≈øt divers of the King's Subjects, to their great Dammage and wrongful Vexation.

For it is not Credible, (≈øaith the Lord Cook, Second Part of his In≈øtitutes, fol. 51.) What horrid Oppre≈ø≈øions and Exactions, to the undoing of Infinite Numbers of People, were Committed by Colour of
that Act, ≈øhaking the Fundamental-Law of the Land: The ill Succe≈øs whereof, and the Fearful Ends of the≈øe Two Oppre≈ø≈øors, ≈øhould deter others from Committing the like; and admoni≈øh Parliaments, That in≈øtead of this Ordinary and Precious Tryal, per Legem Terrae, they bring not in Ab≈øolute and Partial Tryals by Di≈øcretion.

So much touching Emp≈øon and Dudley, tho≈øe Names of Ignomony and Dete≈øtation. Let us now proceed to the Famous Ca≈øe of Ship-Money, in the Reign of King Charles the Fir≈øt, and the Extrajudicial and Ilegal Opinions of the Judges therein Delivered, with the di≈ømal Con≈øequences thereof, as well to them≈øelves, as to the King, and whole Realm.

KING Charles the Fir≈øt came to the Crown 27 March, 1625. In the Three Fir≈øt Years of His Reign, he call'd Three ≈øeveral Parliaments; but none of them Complying to give ≈øo much Money, as was Expected: But rather in≈øi≈øting upon Complaints again≈øt Buckingham, the then Grand Favourite, and to have Publick Grievances Redre≈ø≈øed, They were all Di≈ø≈øolved in Di≈øcontent; and no more Parliaments ≈øpoken of, till that of the Thirteenth of April, 1640. (which was likewi≈øe ≈øuddenly Di≈ø≈øolved.) During this long Interval, or Ab≈øence of tho≈øe whom the Laws had Entru≈øted with Keeping the Right Keys of the Publick Pur≈øe, there were ≈øome that would needs be Tampering to Pick it; I mean, ≈øeveral little Intrigues were ≈øet on Foot, to Supply the Court, and get Money from the Subjects, without their Common Con≈øent in Parliament; (that good Old Cour≈øe, which Never Fail'd any KING, upon any Ju≈øt Occa≈øion, or where they knew it ≈øhould not be diverted to the KING's Di≈øhonor, and the Nations further Grievance) Of this kind were, 1. The Privy Seals i≈ø≈øued. 2. Benevolence required. 3. Commi≈ø≈øions of Loan. 4. The Bu≈øine≈øs of Knighthood; whereby all per≈øons Seiz'd of Lands and Rents of Forty Pounds per Annum, or upwards, were by Proclamation Summon'd, either to appear, and take upon them the Degree of Knighthood, or el≈øe were liable to be Fined for Re≈øpite of the ≈øame. Which (alone ≈øaith Baker, fol. 449.) brought an Hundred Thou≈øand Pounds or more, into the Exchequer.

But all this was ≈øtill thought too little: The≈øe Devices might ≈øerve for a pre≈øent Shift, once, and no more; but there wanted a Continual Fund, or Con≈øtant Supply, as oft as the Court
wanted, or thought fit to require Mony, without being beholden to Parliaments. Whereupon, 5ly. By the fatal Advice (as 'tis ≈øaid) of Noy, the then Attorney General, the King was put upon this Project of rai≈øing Mony, by I≈ø≈øuing out Writs, Commanding his Subjects to be Rated, and A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed in ≈øuch and ≈øuch Sums, for Building, and Equipping of Ships, for the publick Defence of the Kingdom: Which the ≈øaid Attorney per≈øwaded his Maje≈øty might be Ju≈øtified by antient Precedents. In pur≈øuance hereof, the King in the Nineth Year of his Reign, I≈ø≈øued out certain Writs of that kind, to the Sea-Ports, and Maritine Parts of the Realm: And finding (for the mo≈øt part) a punctual Obedience, and good Advantage thereby; it was in ≈øhort time after, advi≈øed to Extend the ≈øame Charge to all the Counties of this Realm, though never ≈øo remote from the Seas; wherein, meeting with ≈øome ‚Ä¢ hat refu≈øed to pay, as Conceiving the ≈øame Unlawful, the Judges (who by their Oaths, are the Kings proper Coun≈øellors in all difficulties concerning the Law) were to be Con≈øulted with. So, a Letter was Written to them, from the King in the≈øe Words: [Baker's Chron. fol. 455.]

body.head: To our Tru≈øty, and well-beloved Sir John Bram≈øton, Knight, Chief Ju≈øtice of our Bench; Sir John Finch, Knight, Chief Ju≈øtice of our Court of Common pleas; Sir Humphrey Davenport, Knight, Chief Baron of our Court of Exchequer; And to the re≈øt of the Judges of our Court of Kings Bench, Common Pleas, and the Barons of our Court of Exchequer.

opener.salute: TRu≈øty and Well-beloved, We greet you well:

body.p:
Taking into our Princely Con≈øideration, that the Honour and Safety of this our Realm of England, (the Pre≈øervation whereof, is Only Entru≈øted to our Care) was, and is more nearly concern'd, than in late or former, times; as well by
divers Coun≈øels, and Attempts to take from us the Dominion of the Seas; of which we are ≈øole Lord, and Right Owner, and Proprietor; and the Lo≈øs whereof, would be of greate≈øt Danger and Peril to this Kingdom, and other our Dominions, and many other ways. We for the avoiding of the≈øe, and the like Dangers; well Weighing with our ≈øelf, that where the Good, and Safety of the Kingdom in general is concern'd, and the whole Kingdom in Danger, there the Charge, and Defence ought to be Borne by all the Realm in general, did for the preventing ≈øo publick a Mi≈øchief, re≈øolve with our ≈øelf, to have a Royal Navy prepared, that might be of Force and Power (with Almighty God's Ble≈ø≈øing and A≈ø≈øi≈øtance) to Protect, and Defend this our Realm, and our Subjects therein, from all ≈øuch Perils and Dangers: And for that purpo≈øe, we I≈ø≈øued forth Writs under our great Seal of England, Directed to all our Sheriffs of our ≈øeveral Counties of England, and Wales; Commanding thereby all our ≈øaid Subjects in every City, Town, and Village, to provide ≈øuch a Number of Ships well-furni≈øh't, as might ≈øerve for this Royal Purpo≈øe; and which might be done with the greate≈øt Equality that could be. In performance whereof, though generally throughout all the Counties of this our Realm, we have found in our Subjects, great Chearfulne≈øs, and Alacrity; which we Graciou≈øly Interpret as a Te≈øtimony, as well of their Dutiful Affection to us, and our Service, as of the Re≈øpect they have to the Publick, which well becometh every good Subject. Neverthele≈øs, finding that ≈øome few happily out of Ignorance, what the Laws and Cu≈øtoms of this Realm are, or out of a de≈øire to be ea≈øed in their Particulars, how General ≈øoever their Charge be, or ought to be, have not yet Paid, and Contributed to their ≈øeveral Rates, and Se≈øsments that were ≈øet upon them. And fore≈øeeing in our Princely Wi≈ødom; divers Suits and Actions, are not unlike to be Commenced, and Pro≈øecuted in our ≈øeveral Courts at We≈øtmin≈øter: We de≈øirous to avoid ≈øuch Inconveniencies, and out of our Princely Love, and Affection to all our People, being willing to prevent ≈øuch Errors as any of our Loving Subjects may happen to run into; have thought fit, in a Ca≈øe of this Nature, to Advi≈øe with you our Judges, who we doubt not are well. Studied, and Informed in the Rights of our Sovereignty; and becau≈øe the Tryals of our ≈øeveral Courts, by the Formalities in Pleading,
will require a long Protraction, We have thought fit by this Letter directed to you All, to require your Judgments in the Ca≈øe, as it is ≈øet down in the Inclo≈øed Paper; which will not only gain Time, but al≈øo be of more Authority to over-rule any Prejudicate Opinions of others in the Point. Given under Our Signet, at Our Court of White-Hall, the Second of February, in the Twelfth Year of Our Reign, 1636.

div.p: The CASE propounded in the Paper inclo≈øed, was thus worded:

body.p: WHen the Good and Safety of the Kingdom (in General) is concern'd, and the whole Kingdom in Danger; Whether may not the KING, by Writ under the Great Seal of England, Command all the Subjects in His Kingdom, at their Charge, to Provide and Furni≈øh ≈øuch Number of Ships with Men, Victuals, and Munition, and for ≈øuch Time as He ≈øhall think fit, for the Defence and Safe-guard of the Kingdom, from ≈øuch Danger and Peril? And by Law compel the Doing thereof, in ca≈øe of Refu≈øal or Refractorine≈øs? And, Whether in ≈øuch Ca≈øe, is not the KING the ≈øole Judge, both of the Danger, and when and how the ≈øame is to be prevented and avoided?

div.p: To which, the J∆≤DGES delivered their Opinions as followeth:

opener.salute: May it plea≈øe Your mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty!

body.p:
WE have, according to Your Maje≈øtie's Command, ≈øeverally, and every Man by him≈øelf, and All of us together, taken into Serious Con≈øideration, the Ca≈øe and Que≈øtions Signed by Your Maje≈øty, and inclo≈øed in Your Letter. And We are of Opinion, That when the Good and Safety of the Kingdom (in General) is Concern'd, and the whole Kingdom in Danger, Your Maje≈øty may, by Writ under the Great Seal of England, Command all the Subjects of This Your Kingdom, at their Charge,
to Provide and Furni≈øh ≈øuch Number of Ships with Men, Victuals, and Ammunition; and for ≈øuch Time, as Your Maje≈øty ≈øhall think fit, for the Defence and Safe-guard of the Kingdom, from ≈øuch Peril and Danger: And that by Law, Your Maje≈øty may Compel the Doing thereof, in ca≈øe of Refu≈øal or Refractorine≈øs. And we are al≈øo of Opinion, That in ≈øuch Ca≈øe, Your Maje≈øty is the ≈øole Judge, both of the Danger, and when and how the ≈øame is to be prevented and avoided.

div.p: But it is to be noted, That though all the Judges did thus Sign this An≈øwer; yet it was not according to all their Opinions; for Crook and Hutton di≈ø-a≈ø≈øented, and declared, That ≈øuch a Charge could not be laid by any ≈øuch Writ; but by Parliament. But the Major-Part of the Judges, being ab≈øolutely Re≈øolved upon that Opinion, pre≈ø≈øed them to Sub≈øcribe likewi≈øe with the re≈øt; for that the Greater Number mu≈øt involve and conclude the Le≈øs; which, they ≈øaid, was u≈øual in all Ca≈øes of Reference; And that the Le≈ø≈øer Number mu≈øt ≈øubmit to the Opinion of the More, although they varied in Opinion: As in the Courts of Law; If Three Judges agree in Opinion again≈øt One or Two, where there is Five Judges, Judgment is to be Entred per Curiam, if the Major Part agree, and the Others are to ≈øubmit unto it, &c. (The≈øe are the very Words of Judge Crook, excu≈øing him≈øelf for having thus Sub≈øcribed: See the Arguments on Hampden's Ca≈øe, p. 12.)

Having thus got the Bu≈øine≈øs back't with the Sub≈øcriptions of all the Judges of England, the ≈øame were Enrolled in all the Courts of Westmin≈øter-Hall: And now, they began to Pro≈øecute briskly, all the Defaulters; among≈øt whom, the Chiefe≈øt was John Hampden of Buckingham-≈øhire, E≈øquire, who had upon one of the≈øe Ship - Writs directed to the Sheriff of that County, been A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Twenty Shillings for his Lands in Stoke-Mandevil, in that County; which not being paid, was Certified (among≈øt others) into the Chancery, upon a Writ of Certiorari, Dated 9
Martii, Anno 12. Car. by a Schedule thereunto annexed; and by a Writ of Mittimus, Te≈øte 5 Maii, 13 Car. tran≈ømitted into the Exchequer; with a Command there, to do for the Leavying of the Sums ≈øo A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed and Unpaid; Prout de Jure, & ≈øecundum, Legem Regni no≈øtri Angliae ≈øuerit faciendum; So as of Right, and according to the Law of our Kingdom of England was to be done; whereupon a Scire Facias i≈ø≈øued out of the Exchequer, reciting the ≈øaid Writs, to warn Mr. Hampden (among≈øt others) to ≈øhew Cau≈øe, why he ≈øhould not be Charged with this Money. Upon this, he being Summoned, Appeared, and demanded Oyer of tho≈øe Writs and Schedule; which being Entred, he Demurr'd in Law; that is, demanded the Opinion and Judgment of the Court of Exchequer, Whether this Writ were ≈øufficient in Law, to Force him to pay the ≈øaid Twenty Shillings.

This being a Great and General Ca≈øe, the Barons of the Exchequer, de≈øired the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the re≈øt of the Judges, who did Joyn accordingly. The Ca≈øe was argued, fir≈øt, by Councel on both Sides; and next, by the Judges ≈øeverally; of whom, Sir Richard Hutton, Knight, one of the Judges of the Common-Pleas, and Sir Richard Crook, Knight, one of the Judges of the King's-Bench, in large and learned Arguments, (≈øince Printed) did ≈øhew the Illegality of ≈øuch Writs, and gave their Opinion; That the Defendant Hampden, ought not to be Charged: But the re≈øt of the Judges were re≈øolved to carry the Point for the King; and accordingly gave their Opinions, That the Defendant ought to be Charged. And then, it was the Part of the Barons of the Exchequer, to give Judgment; which was Entred in the≈øe Words:

Quod ≈øeperalia Brevia predicta, & Retorn' eorundem, ac Schedul' praedict' ei≈ødem Annex', ac materia in ei≈ødem content' ≈øufficient' in Lege Exi≈øt' ad praefat Johannem Hampdem de predictis viginti ≈øolidis ≈øuper ip≈øum informa, & ex cau≈øa praedictae A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øae onerand. Ideo con≈øideratum e≈øt per eo≈ødem Barones quod pr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ctus Johannes Hampden. de ei≈ødem viginti ≈øolidis oneretur, & inde ≈øatisfaciat: That the ≈øaid ≈øeveral Writs and Returns thereof, and the Schedules thereunto annex't, and the Matter in the ≈øame contained, are ≈øufficient in Law to Charge the ≈øaid John Hampden with, the Twenty Shillings upon him, in the Form, and by Vertue of the A≈ø≈øe≈øsment afore-≈øaid impo≈øed. Therefore, it is con≈øidered by the ≈øaid Barons, That the ≈øaid John Hampden ≈øhall be Charged, and ≈øhall ≈øatisfy the ≈øame.

This Judgment was impo≈øed, as ≈øuch an Infallible Determination
of the Law in this Ca≈øe, that no further Di≈øpute would be allow'd thereof to any others; in≈øomuch, that a Per≈øon of Honour, having a Ca≈øe depending in the King's-Bench, was denyed any Argument or Debate, concerning the Right of Ship-Money, for no other Rea≈øon, but that it had been by the former Judgment, decided already in the Exchequer.

It may perhaps be ≈øaid: This Impo≈øition of Ship-Money was ≈ømall and incon≈øiderable; Mr. Hampden, a Gentleman of a fair F≈øtare, was A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed but Twenty Shillings: And, Why ≈øhould any Body-≈øcruple ≈øuch a petty Bu≈øine≈øs, when the King Commanded it? Was not the Remedy far wor≈øe than the Di≈øea≈øe? Why ≈øhould any Subject ex≈øpend a great deal of Money in Law, to avoid Payment of ≈øo Trivial a Sum? Or, What Harm could accrue to the Publick, by the Judges allowing the King Power to Impo≈øe ≈øuch an A≈ø≈øe≈øsment, when it was for the Defence of the Realm from Eminent and Imminent Danger, and he exerted that Power ≈øo favourably, &c.

In An≈øwer to ≈øuch Objections, it mu≈øt be ≈øaid; That true it is, it was then only Mr. Hampden's Ca≈øe; but the whole Nation, every individual Subject of England, was concern'd in it: nay, ≈øo far concern'd, that all his E≈øtate and Liberty was therein given up. The Que≈øtion was not Quantum, but Quo Jure? If Publick Danger might give the King Title to lay Impo≈øitions without a Parliament, and He alone were Judge of ≈øuch Danger, When might it not be alledged? If Twenty Shillings were A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed on Mr. Hampden that Year, How did it appear, but Twenty Pounds might be required the next, and Two Thou≈øand Pounds the Year following? And, What U≈øe, what Occa≈øion would the Court have had for ever afterwards, of a Parliament? But as to the Illegality of the≈øe Ship-Writs, I refer the Reader to Judge Crook's Argument; where the ≈øame is Demon≈øtrated to be again≈øt the Common-Law, again≈øt divers Statutes, not to be maintain'd by any Prerogative, or Power Royal, unwarrantable by any former Precedents, &c.
Let us ≈øee then, what were the Con≈øequences of the≈øe Extrajudicial Opinions, and this Illegal Judgment of the Judges.

Fir≈øt, As to the King: They thereby mi≈ø-led him (as much as in them lay) to Di≈øcompo≈øe the Harmony of Government; to Entrench upon the Property of His Subjects; and (contrary to his Intentions) by Colour of Right, to violate the Laws, which, no doubt, that Good Prince meant to have pre≈øerv'd Inviolable.

Secondly, As to the Subjects: They were not only hereby Injured, but their Affections Alienated from their Sovereign; which to occa≈øion, is no doubt a very High (becau≈øe almo≈øt Irreparable) Trea≈øon.

The Genuine Sen≈øe of the≈øe Re≈øolutions, being no le≈øs than this; That the King of England; as often as Him≈øelf plea≈øeth, may declare the Kingdom to be in Danger, and that ≈øo often, His Maje≈øty, for Prevention of ≈øuch Dangers, may, by His Writ under the Great Seal of England, alter the Property of the Subject's Goods, without their Con≈øent in Parliamen; and that in ≈øuch Proportions, as His Maje≈øty ≈øhall think fit: And be≈øides, may deprive them of the Liberty of their Per≈øons, and that in ≈øuch Manner as Him≈øelf ≈øhall plea≈øe.
Thirdly, As to the Judges them≈øelves: It prov'd de≈øervedly Fatal; For no ≈øooner was a Parliament Call'd, but they were call'd to Account for the≈øe their Illegal Opinions and Judgment.
And after a long Debate, on Monday the Seventh of December, 1640. the≈øe Four ≈øeveral Votes Pa≈ø≈øed upon them, without ≈øo much as One Negative Voice to any of them, viz.

Fir≈øt, THat the Charge impo≈øed upon the Subjects, for the Providing and Furni≈øhing of Ships; and the A≈ø≈øe≈øsments for Rai≈øing of Money for that purpo≈øe, commonly called Ship-Money, are again≈øt the Laws of the Realm, the Subjects Right of Property, and contrary to former Re≈øolutions in Parliament, and to the Petition of Right.

Secondly, That the Extrajudicial Opinions of the Iudges, Publi≈øhed in the Star-Chamber, and Inrolled in the Courts at We≈øtmin≈øter (before Recited) in the whole, and in every part of them are again≈øt the Laws of the Realm, the Right of Property, and the Liberty of the Subjects, and contrary to former Re≈øolutions in Parliament; and to the Petition of Right.

Thirdly, That the Writ to the Sheriff of Bucks (particularly Recited) and the other Writs, commonly called Ship-Writs; are again≈øt the Laws of the Realm, the Right of Property, and the Liberty
of the Subjects, and contrary to former Re≈øolutions in Parliament, and to the Petition of Right.

Fourthly, That the Iudgment in Mr. Hampden's Ca≈øe (as before Recited) in the matter and ≈øub≈øtance thereof; and in that it was conceived that Mr. Hampden was any way Chargeable, is again≈øt the Laws of the Realm, the Right of Property, the Liberty of the Subjects, and contrary to former Re≈øolutions in Parliament, and to the Petition of Right.

The≈øe Votes being Tran≈ømitted by the Commons to the Hou≈øe of Lords; Their Lord≈øhips did Concur therein. And on Fryday the 26. of February, 1640. It was Ordered by the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, in the High Court of Parliament, A≈ø≈øembled; That the Lord-Keeper, or Ma≈øter of the Rolls, the Two Lord Chief Ju≈øtices, and the Lord Chief Baron; and likewi≈øe the Chief Clerk of the Star-Chamber, ≈øhould bring into the Upper Hou≈øe of Parliament, the Records of the Judgment again≈øt Mr. Hampden, concerning Ship-Money, in each of tho≈øe ≈øeveral Courts, and that a Vacat thereof ≈øhould be made. And that a Copy of the Judgment of the Parliament, concerning the Illegality thereof, ≈øhould be Delivered to the ≈øeveral Judges of A≈ø≈øize; and that they ≈øhould be required to Publi≈øh the ≈øame in all the Circuits. Which on the 27. of the ≈øame February, was done accordingly: the ≈øaid Records being Vacated, and the Rolls Cro≈øs'd with a Pen in the Hou≈øe of Lords, and Sub≈øcribed with the Clerk of the Parliament's Hand.

And ≈øoon after, ≈øeveral of the before-named Judges were Impeached for the ≈øame in Parliament: And not daring to ≈øtand the Shock, ≈øome of them, as the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice Finch, Fled beyond the Seas; and others Ab≈øconded. And ≈øoon after, came on the Unnatural Civil-Wars, ≈øo De≈øtructive to King and Kingdom; which, though no way Ju≈øtifiable, yet it cannot be denyed; but they were not a little Occa≈øion'd, and the Animo≈øities of the People, blown into an Untameable Flame, by the≈øe ba≈øe Traiterous Proceedings of tho≈øe Sycophant Judges. And Woe unto tho≈øe (≈øay Sacred Oracles) by whom Offences come.

However, after ≈øo many di≈ømal Experiences, and fair Warnings, and the Miraculous Re≈øtauration of His pre≈øent Maje≈øty,
our Gracious Soveraign (whom God long Pre≈øerve) a Prince of Incomparable Lenity, and Good-natur'd beyond Example; it might be hoped, that none, Preferr'd to the Publick Seats of Ju≈øtice, dur≈øt to have Acted ‚Ä¢ o contrary to His Royal Incimations, as to violate tho≈øe Laws, which He Him≈øelf has Sworn to Maintain, and Intru≈øted them to Admini≈øter: Yet ≈øo Ba≈øe and Extravagant are ≈øome, as even to abu≈øe the Favours of the Be≈øt of Princes, and puff't up with Preferment, will take no Admonition from the Falls of their Head-≈øtrong Predece≈ø≈øors; but ≈øtill pre≈øume to ≈øully tho≈øe Ermins, (the Emblems of Innocency and Integrity) which they wear, and adventure: on the ≈øame De≈øtructive Precipices.

You have heard, how heinou≈øly our Prudent Ance≈øtors re≈øented the Violation of their Liberties, (though by an Act) in Tryals of the Free-born People of England Without Iuries. Next to which, is the Ruffing, Hectoring, and Over-awing of Juries: For, What real Difference is there, betwixt allowing no Juries at all, and Menacing them into a Compliance (contrary to Law, and their own Con≈øciences) with the Corrupt Humours, and Time - ≈øerving Intere≈øts of ill Judges? Of this Crime, the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice Keeling, about the Year 1666. (a Time when God's General Judgments on this Sinful Land, might have awakened them to greater Circum≈øpection and Uprightne≈øs) was not only Guilty, but Que≈øtion'd for the ≈øame, even by That very Parliament, which was never extraordinarily Celebrated for bringing Publick Vermine to Puni≈øhment: Yet ≈øuch a Sen≈øe they had of the≈øe ill Practi≈øes, that in their Journal, we find the following Votes on this Occa≈øion.

body.head: Die Mecurii 11o Decembris, 1667.
body.p: THE Hou≈øe Re≈øuming the Hearing of the re≈øt of the Report, touching the Matter of Re≈øtraint upon Juries; and upon the Examination of divers Witne≈ø≈øes in ≈øeveral Ca≈øes of Re≈øtraints put upon Juries, by the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice Keeling,

Fir≈øt, That the Proceedings of the ≈øaid Lord Chief Ju≈øtice, in the Ca≈øes now Reported, are Innovations in the Tryals of Men for their Lives and Liberties; and that he hath u≈øed an Arbitrary, and Illegal
Power, which is of dangerous Con≈øequence to the Lives and Liberties of the People of England, and tends to the Introducing of an Arbitrary Government.
Secondly, That in the Place of Judicature, the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice hath Undervalued, Vilified, and Contemned Magna Charta; the great Pre≈øerver of our Lives, Liberties, and Property.
Thirdly, That he be brought to Tryal, in Order to Condign Puni≈øhment, in ≈øuch Manner as the Hou≈øe ≈øhall judge mo≈øt Fit and Requi≈øite.

div.p: And again:

body.head: Die Veneris 13o Decembris, 1667.
body.p: THat the Precedents, and Practice, for Fining or Impri≈øoning of Jurors for Giving their Verdicts, is Illegal.

div.p: Here you ≈øee the ill Practices of that Chief Ju≈øtice, were Branded in Parliament, and he was ordered to be Pro≈øecuted; though by rea≈øon of the Hou≈øes being Prorogued, and he him≈øelf not long after Dying in Di≈øcontent, we do not find there were any further Proceedings made therein.

At the Se≈ø≈øions for London, Sept. 1670. William Penn, and William Mead, (Two of the People commonly called Quakers) being Indicted: For that they the Fourteenth of Augu≈øt before, did with others, to the Number of Three Hundred, in Grace-Church-Street, Unlawfully and Tumultuou≈øly A≈ø≈øemble, &c. by rea≈øon whereof a great Tumult did there happen, in Contempt of the King, great Di≈øturbance of the Peace, & Terror of the People, &c. And the Jury (after having been ≈øeveral times ≈øent back, and kept clo≈øe from the Saturday till the Monday Morning) bringing them in Not Guilty, Sir John Howel, then Recorder of London, pre≈øumed to Fine the ≈øaid Jury Forty Marks a Man, and to Lye in Pri≈øon till paid. Being thus in Cu≈øtody, Edward Bu≈øhel, one of the ≈øaid Jury-Men, brought his Habeas Corpus in the Court of Common-Pleas; and upon a long Argument, it was Adjudged by the whole Court, That the ≈øaid Fining and Commitment was Illegal: Whereupon the ≈øaid Bu≈øhel was Di≈øcharged, and left to bring his Action for Fal≈øe Impri≈øonment, again≈øt the ≈øaid Recorder: Which Ca≈øe is Reported by Vaughan, at that time Chief Ju≈øtice of the ≈øaid Court, in his Reports, Licen≈øed and Approved of by the pre≈øent Lord - Chancellor of England, Sir William Scroggs, ≈øince Lord Chief-Ju≈øtice of the King's - Bench, my Lord North,
Chief-Ju≈øtice of the Common-Pleas; and all the Judges of England. But as to the Illegality of any Courts Impo≈øing upon, Menacing, Fineing, or Impri≈øoning Juries, ≈øee a ≈ømall Treati≈øe, Entituled, The Engli≈øh-Man's Right, Printed for R. Janeway, 1680. and another called, The Grand Iury-Man's Oath and Office Explained, Sold by Langley Curtis, on Ludgate-Hill; both well worthy the Peru≈øal of every True Engli≈øh-Man.

What Proceedings have been ≈øince, or rather are at this in≈øtant pendent again≈øt Judges, for Hectoring of Juries, and other Illegal Arbitrary Proceedings, are too fre≈øh in every Bodies Memory, to need a Recital. In≈øtead of which, I ≈øhall rather In≈øert the Form of the Oath, Taken by Judges at their fir≈øt Admittance to that Office; which runs as follows:

body.head: The OATH of a JUDGE. In Dor≈øo Clau≈ø': de Anno 20. Edw. 31. Part. Prima.
body.p:
YE ≈øhall Swear, That Well and Truly ye ≈øhall Serve our Sovereign Lord the King, and His People, in the Office of Ju≈øtice: And that ye ≈øhall Coun≈øel our Sovereign Lord the King, in His Needs: And that ye ≈øhall not give any Coun≈øel, or A≈ø≈øent to any thing, the which might turn to Hurt, or Di≈ø-heriting of the King, by any Way or Colour: And that ye ≈øhall not know any Hurt, or Di≈øheriting of the King; but that ye ≈øhall make it to Him known, by You, or by ≈øome other Per≈øon: And that ye ≈øhall do equal Law and Execution of Right, to all the King's Subjects, Rich and Poor, without having Regard to any Per≈øon: And that ye ≈øhall not take by You, or by any other privily, ne apart, any Gift or Reward of Gold, or of Silver, nor of any other Thing, the which might turn you to Profit, unle≈øs it be Meat or Drink; and that of Little Value, of any Man that ≈øhall have any Plea, or Proce≈øs, hanging before you, as long as the ≈øame before your ≈øelf ≈øuch Pleas and Proce≈ø≈øes ≈øhall be hanging, nor after for that Cau≈øe: And that ye ≈øhall take no Fees, as long as ye be Iu≈øtice, nor Robe of any Per≈øon, great or ≈ømall, in any Ca≈øe, but of the King Him≈øelf: And that ye ≈øhall not give any Coun≈øel, or Advice to any Per≈øon, great or ≈ømall, in any Ea≈øe, where the King is Party: And in ca≈øe that any Per≈øons, of what ever E≈øtate they be of, come before You in Se≈ø≈øions, with Force and Arms, or otherwi≈øe, again≈øt the Peace, or again≈øt the Form of the Statute thereof made, for to di≈øturb the Execution of the Common-Law, or for to Menace the People, that they may not do the Law; That ye ≈øhall Arre≈øt their Bodies, and put them in Pri≈øon; and in ca≈øe they be ≈øuch as ye may not Arre≈øt, that ye ≈øhall Certifie the King of their Names, and of their Mi≈ødoing ha≈øtily; to that End, that he may thereof Ordain Remedy: & that ye ≈øhall not maintain
by your ≈øelf, nor by none other privily nor openly, any Plea or Quarrel hanging in the King's Courts, or el≈øewhere in the Country: And that ye ≈øhall not Delay any Per≈øon of Common-Right, for the Letters of the King, or of any other Per≈øon, nor for any other Cau≈øe: And in ca≈øe that any Letters come to you contrary to the Law, that ye ≈øhall nothing do for ≈øuch Letters, but ye thereof ≈øhall Certifie the King: And ye ≈øhall proceed to do the Law, the ≈øame Letters notwith≈øtanding; and that ye ≈øhall do, And procure the Profit of the King, and his Crown in all Things, where ye them Rea≈øonably may do. And in ca≈øe that ye be found in Default here-after, in any of the Points afore-≈øaid, ye ≈øhall be at the King's Will of Bodies, Lands, and of Honour, to do thereof that that ≈øhall plea≈øe the King.

div.p: This well-contrived, nece≈ø≈øary Oath, pre≈øcribed by the Prudence of our Fore-Fathers, would bear a large Comment; but we mu≈øt ha≈øten, and ≈øhall only remarque:
Fir≈øt, That they Swear, Well and Truly (that is, Uprightly, and according to Law) to Serve the King, and his People.

Secondly, That they ≈øhall do Equal Right, and Execution of Law, to all the King's Subjects, Rich and Poor; (that is, without Partiality, Favour, Malice, &c.) Ju≈øtice is Pictured Blind in re≈øpect of the Subject, not the Object: She has a Ballance, not to weigh Gold, but the Crime: She has regard to Offences, not Per≈øons.

Thirdly, That if any Letters from the King (unduely obtain'd, for ≈øo all ≈øuch are ≈øuppo≈øed to be) ≈øhall be brough to them, contrary to Law, they are not to regard them; much le≈øs are they to value any Verbal Commands, or little Raskally In≈øinuations of any Court-Favourites, huffing Grandees, or ≈ømall Minions of State.

Fourthly, That by this their Oath, Judges are to proceed according to Law; their Bu≈øine≈øs is Jus Dicere, to Declare and Admini≈øter the Laws E≈øtabli≈øh't; not Jus Dare, to Impo≈øe their own Whim≈øical, Arbitrary, Peevi≈øh, or Self-de≈øigning Opinions, for Law; or to U≈øurp a Legi≈ølative Power, ≈øo as deliver that to be Law, which in truth is not ≈øo. And if they ≈øhall pre≈øume to offend herein, they are Exemplarily to be puni≈øhed: For ≈øince 'tis a known Maxime of Law, Ignorantia Juris non excu≈øat, That Ignorance of the Law ≈øhall excu≈øe no Man; (The Rea≈øon of which, is, becau≈øe every Man is ≈øuppo≈øed to be Privy, and con≈øenting to all our Laws, by his Repre≈øentatives in Parliament.) How much le≈øs are Judges (who≈øe Profe≈ø≈øion and Office it is to Under≈øtand the Law; and therefore, mu≈øt take Notice of it, at their Peril) to be Indulg'd? Under what Character will they plead Excu≈øe? Are they Per≈øons of known Learning, and ≈øtrong Natural Parts, great Reading,
exqu≈øite Eloquence, &c? All this but aggravates their Fault, that they ≈øhould abu≈øe ≈øuch good Gifts, to the Di≈øhonour of the King that Commi≈ø≈øions them, and Prejudice of His People that expected more exact Dealings from ≈øuch Eminent Accompli≈øhments. Will they ≈øhelter them≈øelves under the before-mentioned Plea of Ignorance? This is already ≈øhewn to be an Invalid Allegation; and be≈øides, 'tis a Reflection on that Royal Power that Preferr'd them: And, What infinite Mi≈øchiefs (of which there is no Particular Complaint or Information) may the Subjects ≈øuffer in their Lives, and Fortunes, under ≈øuch Ignorance, which is alwayes attended with Equal Pre≈øumption?
