Or, la≈øtly, Suppo≈øe it ≈øhould be offered in their Favour, That for ≈øome time, at fir≈øt, they were Upright, and have had the Reputation of Prudence and Integrity, in all Ca≈øes, except ≈øuch and ≈øuch: for which Now they are que≈øtioned: To this it may be fitly An≈øwer'd, (as he of Lacedemon ≈øaid of the Athenians) If they carryed them≈øelves Well, when Time was, and now Ill, they de≈øerve a Double Puni≈øhment; becau≈øe they are not Good, as they were; and becau≈øe they are Evil, as they were not. The Judges, 'tis true, are declared in the Parliament-Roll of the 11 R. 2. to be Executors of the Statutes, Judgments, and Ordinances of Parliament: But they mu≈øt not make them≈øelves the Executioners of them too, by endeavouring the De≈øtruction of the Fundamentals of our Laws and Liberties. The Law is the Temple, the Sanctuary, whither the Subject is to run for Shelter and Defence: But if the Judges, Sacerdotes Ju≈øtiti ‚Ä¢ e, tho≈øe Priests of Ju≈øtice, ≈øhall, like tho≈øe of Delphos, uttter Fal≈øe, Ambiguous, and Time-Serving Oracles, Where is the Comfort of the Poor Votaries? Will not this Sanctuary then become Templum ≈øine Numine, like that of the Roman Emperour, who after he had built it, put no Gods into it? We ≈øhall have the Dead Killing-Letter of the Law, but not the Quickening, Pre≈øerving Sen≈øe of it: The Fabrick and Formalities of the Temple; but the Godde≈øs A≈øtraea, and the Dii Tutelares, all that ≈øhould Con≈øerve our Liberties and Properties, will be vani≈øh't: And in≈øtead thereof, we ≈øhall have but an Indian Pa-god, a frightful, terrible Idol of Arbitrary Power, delighting in Humane Sacrifices, and only Adorable for Averting that Mi≈øchief, with which it threatens us.

But, Contraria juxta ≈øe po≈øita magis eluce≈øcunt: Contraries illu≈øtrate each other. We have hitherto Treated the Reader with Dole≈øome Narratives of Lewd Judges: Let us now (briefly) Entertain him
with an Account of ≈øome Good and Imitable Ones; Memoria Ju≈øti in Aetermun.

In the Reign of King H. 4. His Son and Heir apparent (then a Wild Youth, but afterwards as Solid, and Renowned a King, as mo≈øt that have ≈øway'd the Engli≈øh Scepter) hearing that one of his Companions was Arraigned for Felony before the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice of England (I am ≈øorry my narrow Reading has not brought me acquainted with his Honourable Name) came to the Bar, and offered to take away the Pri≈øoner by force; but being with≈øtood by the ≈øaid Chief Ju≈øtice, ≈øtepped to him, and Struck him over the Face; whereat the Judge nothing daunted, ro≈øe up, and with a Gravity becoming his Dignity, told him, That he did not this Affront to Him, but to the King his Father, in who≈øe Place he ≈øate; and therefore, forthwith Committed him to Pri≈øon. The Prince Over-aw'd with the Maje≈øty of the Sage Judge's Expre≈ø≈øions, calmly Suffered him≈øelf to be carried away by an ordinary Tip-Staff; which being told the King, He not a little Rejoyced, both that he had a Judge of ≈øuch Couragious Integrity; and a Son of ≈øuch Submi≈ø≈øive Obedience to his Laws, Vide Baker fol. 163.

The Famous Queen Elizabeth, having required a Charge upon divers of Her Subjects, by particular Letters from the Lords of Her Council, of ≈øeveral Sums of Money, for pre≈øent Aid towards Her Wars in Ireland; hearing that one of Her Judges, viz. Mr. Ju≈øtice Walme≈øley, being conven'd before the ≈øaid Lords, for Non-Payment thereof, thereby Di≈øcouraging others; had An≈øwered, That it was Contrary to Law that the ≈øame ≈øhould be Impo≈øed, there being an Expre≈øs Statute again≈øt it; which He being a Judge, was bound by his Oath, to ≈øignifie to Her Maje≈øty, he being (as much as in him lay) a Con≈øervator of the Queens Oath in that behalf; Her Maje≈øty was much Offended, that any ≈øuch Impo≈øition had been pretended to, and Commanded that it ≈øhould be ≈øtopped from further Gathering; and to ≈øuch as had paid it, their Money, by Her expre≈øs Order, was Re≈øtored. Judge Crooks Argument in Hampden's Ca≈øe, p. 57.

In the 29th. of the ≈øame Queen, Her Maje≈øty having Erected a New-Office in the Common-Pleas, for making of Super≈øedeas on Exigents, She Grants it to one Cavendi≈øh Her Servant; ≈øends to have him admitted, but the Judges delay the doing thereof, On this Rea≈øon, becau≈øe the Prothonotaries, and Philizers Claimed the
making tho≈øe Writs. The Queen ≈øends a Sharp Letter, and Commands them forthwith to Admit him: Then She ≈øends a more po≈øitive Command, requiring the Rea≈øon of their Contempt and Di≈øobedience. The Judges return the beforementioned Rea≈øon to the Lord Keeper, and Earl of Leice≈øter (no mean Man in tho≈øe Days) upon which, the Queen ≈øends a Fourth Peremptory Me≈ø≈øage for their Admitting him, with this Rea≈øon: That if the others were put out, they were Rich, and Able Men, and that Her Courts of Ju≈øtice were Open, where they might Demand their Right; for this was not to debar them Therefrom, but only to put them to their Action. The Hone≈øt Judges roturned this An≈øwer, That the Queen had taken Her Oath, for the due Execution of Ju≈øtice According to Law, and they did not doubt, but when Her Maje≈øty was Informed it was again≈øt the Law, She would Act therein as became her. For their own parts, they had taken an Oath to God, to Her, and the Common-Wealth; And if they ≈øhould do it without Proce≈øs of Law before them, and only upon Her Command put the others out of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, though the Right remained to them, it were a Breach of their Oath; and therefore, if the Fear of God were not Sufficient, they told Her the Puni≈øhment, that was Inflicted upon their Predece≈ø≈øors for Breach of their Oaths (citing Thorpe, &c.) might be a ≈øufficient Warning to them: Whereupon the Queen hearing the≈øe Rea≈øons, was Satisfied; and the ≈øaid Judges heard no more of this Bu≈øine≈øs.

To De≈øcend nearer our own Times, we cannot omit that grand Example of Uprightne≈øs, the ever Famous Sir Matthew Hale, late Lord Chief Ju≈øtice of the King's-Bench; a Miracle for all other parts of Polite and Serious Learning, as well as profound Knowledge in the Laws of England. Of whom I ≈øhall yet, not offer any particular In≈øtances, ≈øince his whole Life was one continued Thred of Sincere, and Under≈øtanding Ju≈øtice: For as ea≈øily you might have ju≈øtled the Sun out of the Ecliptick, as to have warp'd him from his con≈øtant Road of Integrity. An exact Standard whereby Future Princes may mea≈øure the Qualifications of their Judges; for though he were a mo≈øt Loyal, and Zealous Servant to the Crown; yet he was ≈øo far from being ever Impeached by the Repre≈øentative Body of the Nation, that no one Single Per≈øon (no not of tho≈øe that were Ca≈øt before him) were ever heard to complain of his Conduct.

And if any Latter Judges have been di≈ømi≈øs'd by fal≈øe Tales of
Sycophant Whi≈øperers, or for oppo≈øing ba≈øe Illegal Arbitrary Intere≈øts; as they have the Invaluable Satisfaction of a good Con≈øcience for their Comfort; ≈øo they may be a≈ø≈øured, they ≈øtill appear more Glorious in the Eyes of all good Engli≈øh-Men at pre≈øent, and will be Recorded more Venerable to Po≈øterity, than any Robes or Preferment, ≈øullied with Bribery, Flattery, or Treacherous Compliances, could renden them.

However, we hope the Various Examples, we have here Enumerated from Authentick Records and Hi≈øtories, may be ≈øufficient to Deterr future Judges from Ill Cour≈øes; and ≈øatisfie all the World, both in the Ju≈øtice of the Parliaments late Proceedings in this Ca≈øe, and the Rea≈øonablene≈øs of their Vote and intended Bill, That Judges henceforth ≈øhould hold their Places, and Salaries, not Ad Placitum; but Quam Diu ≈øe bene ga≈ø≈øerint. Which was the principal Aim of the≈øe Papers. Fiat Ju≈øtitia.
